copingStrategies.name: 5-4-3-2-1 Grounding Technique
copingStrategies.description: A sensory grounding technique to help you stay present and calm anxiety

steps.instruction: Name 5 things you can see around you
steps.detail: Look around and identify 5 specific objects. Say them out loud or in your mind.
Feel 4 different textures or objects around you. Notice their temperature, roughness, or softness.
Listen for 3 different sounds in your environment. This could be traffic, birds, your own breathing.
Notice 2 different scents around you. If you can't smell anything, remember 2 of your favorite scents.
Notice any taste in your mouth, or think of your favorite taste.

accessibility.visualImpairment: Can be adapted to focus more on other senses
accessibility.hearingImpairment: Visual and tactile elements remain effective

copingStrategies.name: Box Breathing (4-4-4-4)
copingStrategies.description: A structured breathing technique used by Navy SEALs and meditation practitioners

steps.detail: Inhale through your nose, filling your lungs completely. Count: 1... 2... 3... 4...
Keep the air in your lungs. Count: 1... 2... 3... 4...
Exhale through your mouth, emptying your lungs completely. Count: 1... 2... 3... 4...
Keep your lungs empty. Count: 1... 2... 3... 4...
Continue this pattern. You can adjust the count if 4 feels too long or short.

variations.name: 4-7-8 Breathing
variations.description: Inhale for 4, hold for 7, exhale for 8. Good for sleep.

variations.name: Shorter Box
variations.description: Use 3-3-3-3 if 4 counts feel too long.

copingStrategies.name: STOP Technique
copingStrategies.description: A quick mindfulness practice to interrupt negative thought patterns

steps.detail: Literally pause whatever activity you're engaged in. This breaks the cycle.
Take one slow, deep breath. This activates your parasympathetic nervous system.
Notice what's happening in your mind and body without judgment. What are you thinking? What are you feeling?
Continue with whatever you were doing, but with greater awareness and intention.

copingStrategies.name: Safe Space Visualization
copingStrategies.description: Create a mental sanctuary where you feel completely safe and peaceful

steps.instruction: Find a comfortable position and close your eyes
steps.detail: Sit or lie down comfortably. If closing your eyes feels unsafe, soften your gaze downward.
Allow your breathing to slow and deepen naturally.

steps.instruction: Imagine a place where you feel completely safe
steps.detail: This could be real or imaginary - a beach, forest, childhood bedroom, or fantasy location.

steps.instruction: Add details using all your senses
steps.detail: What do you see? Hear? Smell? Feel? Make it as vivid as possible.

steps.instruction: Notice the feeling of safety and peace
steps.detail: Allow yourself to fully experience the calm, secure feeling of this space.

steps.instruction: Know you can return here anytime
steps.detail: Remember that this safe space is always available to you in your mind.

copingStrategies.name: Progressive Muscle Relaxation
copingStrategies.description: Systematically tense and relax muscle groups to release physical tension

steps.detail: Tense your toe muscles for 5 seconds, then release and notice the relaxation.

steps.instruction: Work up through your feet and calves
steps.detail: Tense each muscle group for 5 seconds, then release.
Tense, hold for 5 seconds, then release and notice the contrast.
Tense your core muscles, hold, then release.
Make fists, tense your arms, hold, then release.

steps.instruction: Finish with shoulders, neck, and face
steps.detail: Scrunch up your face, tense your neck and shoulders, then release everything.

copingStrategies.name: Cognitive Reframing
copingStrategies.description: Challenge and reframe negative or distorted thoughts

steps.detail: What exactly is going through your mind? Write it down if helpful.
Consider the evidence for and against this thought.
Even if true, is thinking this way helping or hurting you?
What would you tell a friend in this situation? What else could be true?
Develop a more balanced, realistic, and helpful way of thinking about the situation.

copingStrategies.name: Emotional Check-In
copingStrategies.description: Tune into your current emotional state with compassion

steps.detail: Create a moment of stillness to turn inward.

steps.instruction: Ask: What am I feeling right now?
steps.detail: Name the emotion(s). It's okay if there are multiple or if you're not sure.

steps.instruction: Where do I feel this in my body?
steps.detail: Notice physical sensations - tight chest, clenched jaw, heavy shoulders.
Consider what might help - comfort, movement, expression, rest.
Remember that all emotions are valid and temporary.

quickTechniques.name: Three Deep Breaths
quickTechniques.instruction: Take three slow, deep breaths. Inhale through nose, exhale through mouth.

quickTechniques.name: Cold Water on Face/Wrists
quickTechniques.instruction: Run cold water over your wrists or splash on your face to activate the dive response.

quickTechniques.name: Full Body Tense and Release
quickTechniques.instruction: Tense every muscle for 5 seconds, then release everything at once.
